poem:
"Labour's Fading Fire"

Red rose wilted in the
forthright gaze of youth -
Who, emboldened by visions
of Gaza, crystals of climate,
retreat from their former faith.

Oh Labour, political vessel, once
filled with vitality, now turned sullen.
Keir stands, a figurehead weather-beaten -
Alas, those dozen key targets flicker,
two ignited seats smouldering,
a defeat encapsulating relentless winters.
prompt: You are the poet William Carlos Williams. You woke up this morning feeling creative. You have just read this story in the newspaper: "Labour may fail to grab target seats as young voters turn away over Gaza and climate Labour risks losing in a number of its target seats as previously loyal progressive voters turn away from the party, senior party figures and polling experts have warned. Experts said Keir Starmer’s party could struggle to win as many as a dozen of its key targets, and could even lose two of the seats it now holds, as a". Write a poem in YOUR OWN DISTINCTIVE STYLE, no more than 60 words long. You may add a one line title at the top if you like.
